thread.title: From Liverpool to Glossop - the all-time top flight table
thread.title_full: From Liverpool to Glossop - the all-time top flight table | Daily Mail Online

author: Ben Grounds For Mailonline
title: From Liverpool to Glossop - the all-time top flight table
text:
Manchester United racked up their 2,000th point in the Premier League era as goals from Juan Mata and Anthony Martial gave them a routine 2-0 win over Watford at Old Trafford on Saturday.
The result kept Jose Mourinho's side within a point of the Champions League places, but despite the milestone achievement for the club against the Hornets, United are still some 254 points behind rivals Liverpool in the all-time top flight standings.
Football database Statto.com have provided the complete all-time table from the 1888-89 season to the present day, including 34 games for Glossop North End - still the smallest town whose team has played in the English top flight.
Manchester United hit 2,000 top-flight points after they beat Watford 2-0 at Old Trafford
25th-placed Leicester City are the lowest-ranked top-flight champions of the last 55 years
The Derbyshire club were in the top flight of English football in 1899-1900, playing in a First Division containing Liverpool, Everton and Newcastle, when Aston Villa finished as champions.
Of course, Aston Villa were Premier League ever-presents until this season, and they along with Newcastle are two current Championship sides in the top 10.
Blackburn, who won the Premier League in 1995, are now staring relegation to the third tier firmly in the face, but the Lancashire club are a very respectable 12th on the list given their 72 seasons in the top flight in their 142-year history.
Despite Chelsea's dominance in the Premier League this season, they are still 579 points off overtaking Villa in fifth place, but United will have their sights set on catching Everton in third over the next few seasons.
Liverpool celebrate the First Division title in 1990 the last time they were league champions
Huddersfield Town gear up for the opening day of the 1971-72 season, their last in the top flight
Only 14 of the 65 clubs to have played in the top flight have a positive goal difference, while Swansea's 2-0 victory over Leicester was their 100th top-flight win.
Paul Clement returns to Chelsea next weekend for the Swans' 300th game in the top flight while of the current sides in the Premier League, Bournemouth boast the fewest number of games (62).
League One Bolton Wanderers have enjoyed far better days and are 13th in the standings, while 30th-placed Huddersfield Town are in the Championship play-off places, hoping to add to their 1260 top-flight games next season - the last of which came in the 1971-72 season.
